title: Looking Sleek: Here Are Several Good Looks at the Vivo X Fold 5
description: The Vivo X Fold 3's successor is set to level it up in the visual category.
author: Ayomide Sadiq
excerpt: The Vivo X Fold 3's successor is set to level it up in the visual category.

I'm getting pretty excited about foldables these days. In a generation or two, I expect the formula to have been perfected, with devices that are slim and light, yet still manage to fit flagship specs. Isn't that all someone should want when buying cutting-edge technology that costs nearly $2,000? The Vivo X Fold 5 is coming out soon and will have a chance to advance the foldable formula a step further. It is already expected to be slimmer and lighter than its predecessor. And like the phone before it, it might come with a killer camera setup. Thanks to a major leak, we've gotten our best look so far at the upcoming foldable. From Essentially All Angles, the Vivo X Fold 5 Looks Amazing Image: Evan Blass on X The Royole Flexpai was the first foldable, and despite one sequel, the company quickly fell off the map after forcing itself into the history books. These days, no smartphone company is making foldables and dealing in half-measures (well, maybe Samsung), so it is better that a player like Royole got weeded out quickly. For instance, the Vivo X Fold 3, which came out last year, was a good example of how great foldable cameras can be. The Vivo X Fold 5 is coming to succeed that device, skipping over the number 4 thanks to tetraphobia, and it seems set to improve on what was already a solid formula. Thanks to Evan Blass on X, we've gotten a really solid look at the device's design. No, this leak doesn't come with anything spec-related, but that's fine. The Colorways for the Vivo X Fold 5 Might Be Confirmed Image: Evan Blass on X Image: Evan Blass on X From all of the leaked images (and videos), we can see the X Fold 5 in three different colorways, and if you ask me, those will likely be the only three options for the device. Vivo covers the neutral colors and adds one that's more vibrant, and that pretty much nails what people tend to look for. The color options will be: Black White Green Image: Evan Blass on X Image: Evan Blass on X Of course, they're going to have fancy names, but for now, we don't know those. I'm a big fan of the green variant, and if I were in line for the device, that'd be the one I'd opt for. The X Fold 5 Will Be Very Light, It Seems Video: Evan Blass on X Some of the marketing videos for the X Fold 5 have leaked, and in those, we see a more playful side of the Chinese OEM. While it is clearly exaggerating in some of these videos, the company plays around to show how light the phone is going to be. Apparently, it'll be light enough for an ant to carry, light enough to land on a spider web without breaking through it, and light enough to flutter like a butterfly. The Vivo X Fold 3 weighed 219 grams. While I don't expect the Vivo X Fold 5 to go sub-200g, we should see a notable weight reduction. Thinness Can't Be Compromised This Year Video: Evan Blass on X Of course, the X Fold 5 will be thinner than Vivo's foldable last year, since slimness is one of the most critical metrics for foldables right now. Its predecessor was 4.7mm thin when unfolded, and I'm estimating that it might shave off half a millimeter at best. If it manages to do anything more than that, I'll be shocked. Vivo has said it will be the thinnest foldable released, so it has quite a bit of competition to surpass when it launches later this month. I'm getting pretty excited about foldables these days. In a generation or two, I expect the formula to have been perfected, with devices that are slim and light, yet still manage to fit flagship specs. Isn't that all someone should want when buying cutting-edge technology that costs nearly $2,000?

The Vivo X Fold 5 is coming out soon and will have a chance to advance the foldable formula a step further. It is already expected to be slimmer and lighter than its predecessor. And like the phone before it, it might come with a killer camera setup. Thanks to a major leak, we've gotten our best look so far at the upcoming foldable.

From Essentially All Angles, the Vivo X Fold 5 Looks Amazing

The Royole Flexpai was the first foldable, and despite one sequel, the company quickly fell off the map after forcing itself into the history books. These days, no smartphone company is making foldables and dealing in half-measures (well, maybe Samsung), so it is better that a player like Royole got weeded out quickly. For instance, the Vivo X Fold 3, which came out last year, was a good example of how great foldable cameras can be.

The Vivo X Fold 5 is coming to succeed that device, skipping over the number 4 thanks to tetraphobia, and it seems set to improve on what was already a solid formula. Thanks to Evan Blass on X, we've gotten a really solid look at the device's design. No, this leak doesn't come with anything spec-related, but that's fine.

The Colorways for the Vivo X Fold 5 Might Be Confirmed

From all of the leaked images (and videos), we can see the X Fold 5 in three different colorways, and if you ask me, those will likely be the only three options for the device. Vivo covers the neutral colors and adds one that's more vibrant, and that pretty much nails what people tend to look for. The color options will be:

  • Black
  • White
  • Green

Of course, they're going to have fancy names, but for now, we don't know those. I'm a big fan of the green variant, and if I were in line for the device, that'd be the one I'd opt for.

The X Fold 5 Will Be Very Light, It Seems

Some of the marketing videos for the X Fold 5 have leaked, and in those, we see a more playful side of the Chinese OEM. While it is clearly exaggerating in some of these videos, the company plays around to show how light the phone is going to be.

Apparently, it'll be light enough for an ant to carry, light enough to land on a spider web without breaking through it, and light enough to flutter like a butterfly. The Vivo X Fold 3 weighed 219 grams. While I don't expect the Vivo X Fold 5 to go sub-200g, we should see a notable weight reduction.

Thinness Can't Be Compromised This Year

Of course, the X Fold 5 will be thinner than Vivo's foldable last year, since slimness is one of the most critical metrics for foldables right now. Its predecessor was 4.7mm thin when unfolded, and I'm estimating that it might shave off half a millimeter at best. If it manages to do anything more than that, I'll be shocked.

Vivo has said it will be the thinnest foldable released, so it has quite a bit of competition to surpass when it launches later this month.

Through Tecno, Gionee, Vivo, Google, and now Samsung, Ayomide has always been an Android enthusiast. His current partner in crime is a Samsung Galaxy S22 Ultra. You can find him playing Candy Crush or Call of Duty: Mobile, watching movies, and he is a big fan of trivia and quizzes.
